title: Intro to React
description: Everything you need to know to start React from scratch.

sections.content: React is a powerful JavaScript library for building user interfaces. In this comprehensive guide, I'll walk you through the fundamentals of React development.
What is React?
React is a declarative, efficient, and flexible JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It lets you compose complex UIs from small and isolated pieces of code called 'components'.
Key Concepts
Getting Started

npx create-react-app my-app
cd my-app
npm start
This will create a new React project with all the necessary dependencies and start the development server.
Your First Component
This simple example shows how components work in React. The Welcome component receives props and renders them in JSX.
State Management
State allows components to manage their own data and re-render when that data changes.
Best Practices

items: Extract reusable logic into custom hooks

sections.content: React is an excellent choice for building modern web applications. Its component-based architecture and rich ecosystem make it a powerful tool for developers.

title: GDnet Project Overview
description: How I made my minimalistic educational Deep Learning framework using CuPy for GPU acceleration

sections.content: Kick off

I always wanted to understand how deep learning frameworks like TensorFlow or PyTorch really worked. So I dove into the math and wrote a basic NumPy-based neural net.

At first, I thought: ‚ÄúEasy ‚Äî just W¬∑X + B and boom, done.‚Äù

That was just the forward pass.

Then came backpropagation ‚Äî and the math nearly broke me. That‚Äôs where the real magic is. Once I understood it, building layers was straightforward ‚Äî just abstracted groups of neurons.

Then came batching. I had no clue what it was‚Ä¶ until my model took 10 minutes per epoch. Turns out, batching wasn‚Äôt optional ‚Äî it was necessary.

That was just the beginning!
Success!? MNIST came back with 95% accuracy ü§Ø

I was shocked ‚Äî 95% accuracy on MNIST! Total dopamine rush. I had only implemented basic layers: Dense, ReLU, Softmax, and batching.

Then I discovered CNNs. Everyone said they boosted accuracy, so I jumped in.

Implementing convolutions was chaos. I kinda understood the theory, but putting it into code? Painful. I ended up writing a 5-deep for-loop üòµ. Training time exploded to 5+ hours.

I knew I had to vectorize it. Tried using NumPy ‚Äî didn‚Äôt go well.
Roadblock?! How to stand on the shoulders of giants

I kept wondering how frameworks like TensorFlow were so fast.

My code took 20 minutes per epoch on MNIST ‚Äî TF? One second.

I realized they weren‚Äôt cheating ‚Äî just optimizing everything under the hood in C/C++.

So I 'cheated' too: I used PyTorch convolutions. But I still implemented im2col, col2im, and optimized other internals myself.

And after all that?

98% accuracy on MNIST. Felt like standing on the shoulders of giants‚Ä¶ while wearing DIY shoes.
So I implemented this ‚Äî when did the reality hit?

I was hyped. 98% on MNIST.

So I built a Tkinter UI and tried testing it with my own handwriting.

The model failed. Badly.

That‚Äôs when it hit me ‚Äî test accuracy doesn‚Äôt mean real-world accuracy.

I dove into production ML concepts and found data augmentation. Implementing flips, shifts, and rotations was fine. Zooming? Absolute nightmare üíÄ

But it worked. After retraining, accuracy dropped to 96.9%, but generalization massively improved.

Now it was correctly predicting 9/10 digits.

ü•≥ Redemption.
Next steps? Language processing ‚úîÔ∏è

I got bored of image data. MNIST, EMNIST ‚Äî all felt the same.

So I jumped into NLP. Built a `TextManager` using `TfidfVectorizer` to convert text to numbers.

I grabbed a Kaggle dataset to classify hate speech. Since I already had Softmax and CrossEntropy, it felt easy.

Then it all broke.

No matter what I typed ‚Äî the model always said ‚Äúhate speech.‚Äù

Turns out the dataset was 85% hate, 15% normal. Total class imbalance.

I learned a tough lesson: NLP isn‚Äôt image classification with words. I tried using class weights, tweaking losses ‚Äî but nothing pushed accuracy past 20% on non-hate examples.

So yeah‚Ä¶ NLP dreams postponed. ü™¶
Idk anymore. Focused on other projects for a while

After a break, I circled back to GDNet. But I was kinda lost.

Then I remembered a side project ‚Äî weather prediction.

Time series seemed fun, so I learned about RNNs and LSTMs. Wrote a full LSTM model.

Felt great‚Ä¶ until YouTube betrayed me with:

‚ÄúWhy RNNs Are Bad?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat Replaced LSTMs?‚Äù

I watched them and learned about **Attention** ‚Äî and the legendary paper, ‚ÄúAttention Is All You Need.‚Äù

I was hooked.

I built Transformer blocks: MultiHeadAttention, LayerNorm, FFN, all of it.

Trained a tiny GPT-like model:

- 100k tokens
- 30k vocab
- 10 epochs
- ~30% accuracy
- Estimated 67 days to train a proper one üíÄ

Tried matrix decomposition on the attention layers to speed things up ‚Äî worked *a little*.

Then I tried reusing my CNN model...

It broke everything.

My ‚Äúframework‚Äù was a 1.1k-line Python file stitched with hope üòÇ
I sat and modularized my modules for the next 5 hours

Thankfully, the whole codebase was just 1.1k lines ‚Äî but refactoring still hurt.

As I cleaned up, I realized I had been obsessed with layers, and ignored the rest:

- üß† Optimizers (SGD isn‚Äôt everything)
- üî¢ Activation functions beyond ReLU
- üìâ Loss functions
- üìè Regularization techniques

So I went all in ‚Äî explored everything. The framework finally started to feel legit.

If you're curious how DL frameworks actually work ‚Äî feel free to check it out!

Yeah, the code is messy (handcrafted with love üòÖ), but readable, and easy to follow with a quick web search.
Main Villains:

üü• ShapeMismatchError
üîÅ CuPy vs NumPy mismatch
üì° Broadcasting errors
üòµ‚Äçüí´ Random NaNs out of nowhere
üëø Derivative of Softmax

title: üöÄ My Journey with the Sastranet Team: From Fan to Family
description: How I joined a legendary student-led team that built an app to transform our university experience

sections.content: When I first came across Sastranet, I was blown away.

It was a group of my seniors ‚Äî third-years, already preparing for placements ‚Äî who came together to build something that truly changed the student experience at our university. They saw all the pain points of living and navigating college life through outdated, clunky websites... and instead of just complaining, they did something about it.
Out of nowhere ‚Äî boom üí• ‚Äî this clean, unified app drops, and it just explodes.

The downloads? Through the roof.
The buzz? Everywhere.
It quickly became the app everyone was using ‚Äî students literally shifted their digital campus life into this single, beautiful platform.

From schedules to notices, fee updates to results, everything was finally in one place. And it wasn‚Äôt just functional ‚Äî it was smooth, well-designed, and felt like it was made by people who actually understood student life.
That‚Äôs when I knew... This wasn‚Äôt just some side project. This was a revolution in our university tech ecosystem.
ü§ù First Contact: Joining the Mission

Then one day‚Ä¶ I opened Sastranet and saw a small banner:
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre expanding ‚Äî second years, come join the team.‚Äù
No way. Was this real? The people behind Sastranet were looking for juniors to carry the torch forward?
The process began with a few rounds:
‚úÖ 1. Google Form (That scared off half the crowd üò≠)
They started with a basic form ‚Äî name, year, experience‚Ä¶ and then boom, a section for: ‚ÄúAny technical achievements or projects?‚Äù

It freaked a lot of people out. Many assumed they weren‚Äôt ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù and never even submitted the form. But the Sastranet team didn‚Äôt intend to scare anyone off ‚Äî they were genuinely looking for passion and interest, not polished portfolios. Still, that one section filtered out a lot üòÖ
üß† 2. Coding Round: Build Fast, Build Smart
Next came a timed challenge ‚Äî 45 minutes to build a quick React-based UI.

They allowed the use of AI tools too (huge W). Most applicants focused on clean, easy sections. I, for some reason, went head-first into the complex parts first... and struggled to finish the simpler ones. But I showed them my past projects to make up for it.
That edge? It worked. ‚úÖ
üßÆ 3. DSA Round: LeetCode Flex Time
The third round was a classic DSA problem ‚Äî easy-to-medium level.
I‚Äôd already solved 380+ problems on LeetCode (weird flex but okay üòé), so this one went smooth.
üé§ 4. The Vibe Check (HR Round)
Honestly? This was the best part.
A super chill conversation where they tried to see if I was a good fit for the team culture. I vibe well, talk well, and they seemed to like that. And just like that‚Ä¶ I was in. LET‚ÄôS GOOOO üéâ
üõ†Ô∏è The Real Work Begins
Fast-forward a bit ‚Äî six of us new recruits joined the team. We started onboarding, tackling bugs, making small features, and gradually leveling up.

We weren‚Äôt just thrown into the fire ‚Äî we had support from seniors, who were always ready to help, share time management tips, and mentor us on everything from Git branches to CI/CD pipelines of a professional product.
And the best part? The team culture.

items: You can suggest, debate, and build freely ‚Äî as long as it aligns with the larger roadmap.
You can take ownership, build your way, and still move as one unit.

sections.content: We laughed, debugged, panicked, and fixed things together ‚Äî and honestly, it‚Äôs been one of the most growth-packed experiences of my college life so far.
üåü Final Thoughts
Sastranet isn‚Äôt just an app. It‚Äôs a movement ‚Äî built by students, for students.

Being part of this team means more than just writing code ‚Äî it‚Äôs about creating impact. It‚Äôs about solving real problems for real people around you, and doing it with a team that supports and uplifts you every step of the way.
I‚Äôm super grateful to be part of this journey. Here‚Äôs to what comes next. ü´°
ü•π Forever proud to be a part of the Sastranet crew.
